# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Based on the task and special instructions provided, here's a function in Julia that wraps a string into lines of a specified maximum width:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    lines = []
    current_line = ""

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = word
        else
            current_line = current_line * " " * word
        end
    end

    if !isempty(current_line)
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end

    return lines
end
```

You can use this function to wrap a string like so:

```julia
text = "The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog"
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, 10)

for line in wrapped_text
    println(line)
end
```

This will output:

```
The quick
brown fox
jumps over
the lazy
dog
```

The function `wrap_string` takes a string `text` and an optional integer `text_width` which defaults to 10. It splits the text into words and then iterates over each word, adding it to the current line if it doesn't exceed the `text_width`, or starting a new line if it does. The wrapped lines are returned as an array of strings.
